prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: [CII] in G244.8+54.9
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
We will map [CII] line emission in Band 8 at 0.3" resolution for a source size of 1.5".
Configuration 36-3 to reach 0.3" beam in band 9. The source will be on the night sky during the scheduling of this configuration.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We reference our estimates to 100 km/s for the sensitivity estimate, which will enable us to probe the line profile with about 5-10 resolution elements, sufficient to probe the basic line profile. For the faintest regions this will be adequate. For the highest-surface brightness regions, we might use the intrinsic channel width instead, depending on the surface brightness reached, which would enable more detailed analysis of individual line components.

We request 0.3" resolution, one of the coarser resolutions of band 8. This can be done in configuration C36-3, when the source will be on the night-sky in cycle 3. The Einstein ring is 1.5" in diameter, and we expect to find several bright clumps, each isolated in a 0.3" beam with SMA, and covered individually with a 0.3-0.5" beam with ALMA. The LAS is simply the diameter of the Einstein ring. Slightly lower resolutions because of the Northern RA are not critical.

We use the SPIRE 500-mu measurement to estimate the continuum flux density, and our measured FIR luminosity and the observed L(CO)/L(FIR)=1.5d-3 from Stacey et al, (2010) to estimate our line flux requirements. The FWHM is estimated from our CO line profiles. The source size of 1.5" comes from our SMA interferometry at 0.3" beam. For G244.8 we expect a ([CII]) flux of 747.7 Jy km/s, and a peak flux density of 1.0 Jy for a 700 km/s wide line. Using the ETC we find we can reach 8 mJy rms in a 100 km/s channel in 16. min on-source, and 54 min of total integration time. This will give SNR=125 for the total source and be sufficient to map the source with a 0.3" beam (5-10 apertures along a 1.5" diameter ring, that is unresolved perpendicular to the ring itself, i.e. SNR=12-25 per beam.). This corresponds to weather conditions in the 1st octile. We place additional sub-bands on the continuum to enable good mapping of the star-formation and dust properties (spectral index, temperatures).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: [CII] in G045.1+61.1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
We will map [CII] in Band 8 in this source at 0.3" resolution. The source consist of several clumps in the 0.8" CO map obtained with IRAM at the PdBI (see science justification). The largest has a length of about 2".
Configuration 36-3, giving 0.3" resolution in band 8. The source can be observed during night time in this configuration.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We aim at resolving the line profiles down to about 50 km/s for the source generally, so we can measure line profiles for FWHM=270 km/s. We might increase this to the total resolution offered by the correlator in case that the surface brigthness is high enough in parts of the source.
We wish to resolve individual counter images that are each unresolved in the PdBI map at 0.8" resolution. Slightly lower resolutions because of the Northern RA are not critical.

We use the SPIRE 500 mu measurement as estimate of the continuum flux density and our measured FIR luminosity and the observed L(CO)/L(FIR)=1.5d-3 from Stacey et al, (2010) to estimate our line flux requirements. The FWHM is estimated from our CO line profiles. The source size is measured from our IRAM PdBI interferometric map at 0.8" resolution. In G080.3 where we already have both Spitzer and (sub-)mm interferometry at subarc resolution (see scientific justification) the SPITZER contours match those of the dust and CO. For G045.3 we expect a ([CII]) flux of 269.5 Jy km/s, and a peak flux density of 0.8 Jy for a 270 km/s wide line. Using the ETC we find we can reach 3 mJy rms in a 50 km/s channel in 34 min on-source, and 1.14 of total integration time at an observed frequency of 434 GHz. This will give SNR=300 for the total source and be sufficient to map the source with a 0.3" beam in about 15-20 beams, as suggested by the morphology in our PdBI interferometric maps of CO. We will need weather conditions in the 1st octile. We place additional subbands on CO(16-15) and two continuum tunings as a bonus, which does not motivate our sensitivity estimate.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: [CII] in G231.3+72.2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
We wish to observe [CII] in G231.3 at 0.3" beam size.
Configuration C36.3. The source will be observable during the night in this configuration.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request 50 km/s in the sensitivity estimate which will allow us to resolve and measure the line profile, FWHM of the line, and velocity gradients. The spectral window is large enough to cover the line and adjacent continuum (as for all sources requested here).

We aim at obtaining a spatially resolved map of this source, which is about 2.5" large in the PdBI map of CO. Note that the source flux is not evenly distributed within 2.5" but along a ring, so that we expect about 20 individual resolution elements. Slightly lower resolutions because of the Northern RA are not critical.

We use the SPIRE 500 mu measurement as estimate of the continuum flux density and our measured FIR luminosity and the observed L(CO)/L(FIR)=1.5d-3 from Stacey et al, (2010) to estimate our line flux requirements. The FWHM is estimated from our CO line profiles. We know from our PdBI maps of CO that this source is a near-complete ring with a diameter of about 2.5". The source is unresolved in the direction perpendicular to the lensing axis. We expect a ([CII]) flux of 300 Jy km/s, and a peak flux density of 1.2 Jy for a 270 km/s wide line. Using the ETC we find we can reach 3 mJy rms in a 50 km/s channel in 25 min on-source, and 55 min of total integration time at an observed frequency of 490 GHz. This will give SNR=360 for the total source and be sufficient to map the source with a 0.3" beam and resolve the ring into about 20 individual resolution elements. This corresponds to weather conditions in the 1st octile.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: [CII] in G200.6+46.1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Goal is to map [CII] in this galaxy.
Configuration C36.3 will allow to reach 0.3" resolution in band 8. The source will be observable at night time during this run in cycle 3.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request 50 km/s in the sensitivity estimate which will allow us to resolve and measure the line profile, FWHM of the line, and velocity gradients. The spectral window is large enough to cover the line and adjacent continuum (as for all sources requested here).

We aim at obtaining a spatially resolved map of this source, which is about 2.5" large in the PdBI map of CO. Note that the source flux is not evenly distributed within 2.5" but along a ring, so that we expect about 20-30 individual resolution elements from our existing CO maps. Slightly lower resolutions because of the Northern RA are not critical.

We use the SPIRE 500 mu measurement as estimate of the continuum flux density and our measured FIR luminosity and the observed L(CO)/L(FIR)=1.5d-3 from Stacey et al, (2010) to estimate our line flux requirements. The FWHM is estimated from our CO line profiles. We know from our PdBI maps of CO that this source is a near-complete ring with a diameter of about 2.5". The source is unresolved in the direction perpendicular to the lensing axis. We expect a ([CII]) flux of 200 Jy km/s, and a peak flux density of 0.8 Jy km/s for a 270 km/s wide line. Using the ETC we find we can reach 2 mJy rms in a 50 km/s channel in 25 min on-source, and 55 min of total integration time at an observed frequency of 478 GHz. This will give SNR=400 for the total source and be sufficient to map the source with a 0.3" beam and resolve the ring into about 20-30 individual resolution elements. This corresponds to weather conditions in the 1st octile.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We will observe [CII] at 0.3'' resolution in band 8 in 4 of the brightest, strongly gravitationally lensed high-redshift galaxies on the sub-mm sky probed by Planck. With magnification factors >/~20, such galaxies provide unprecedented insight into the fine spatial details of the most vigorously star-forming galaxies in the early Universe. We have started a comprehensive multi-wavelength follow-up to constrain gas, dust, and star-formation in these galaxies and the mechanisms that set the star-formation law in vigorous starbursts at high-z. With [CII] we will measure the total UV heating budget from star formation and perhaps other mechanisms like shocks. Combination with other mm lines will inform various line diagnostics, including gas densities and radiation fields. Velocity gradients and line profiles will constrain gas turbulence and rotation, and may indicate a merger or winds. These observations were already approved in Cycle 2 in the 10-20% range, but not yet observed. We re-request them here with an even stronger science case and new observational constraints, that rule out the main concerns of the cycle 2 TAC regarding sizes and surface brightness.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
